pros:
International environment
Generally good colleagues across the markets
Lots of learning opportunities and generally good if you are mobile
cons:
Significant amount of cronyism and relationship-based decisioning evidenced by the number of senior (MD) roles that are arguably redundant. In fact, they create more work through the kinds of reviews each of them wants.

Some pockets of seriously poor talent management inclinations by senior management

Lots of seniors still stuck in 1990s banking. Insistence on old-school obsolete ways.

review_title: Toxic culture depends on which department
pros: As a company its great.
cons: Was unfortunate who has a boss who micromanaged too much and doesn't agree with your decision even the problem is there. Just want everything to show that he knows everything.

review_title: It was a Great Place to Work until recently
pros: Over the years, I have seen how the organization has grown, led the way in many areas, taken risks on people.  There is great Diversity there so really good if you enjoy working with International cultures and if you are passionate about gender diversity.
cons: Tends to be network based which makes it difficult for new joiners to figure out how to get things done.

pros: Culture is great as far as I am concerned. I love the people I got to work with. Great employee benefits.
cons: No work life balance - Your commission is almost directly proportionate to the amount of time you put in at work. There are going to be people who want to cannibalise you in this line of work, always watch your back, and take everything you hear with a pinch of salt.

pros: Senior management are accessible and opened to new ideas and disruption
cons: Too slow in implementing organizational changes, leading to unnecessary uncertainty

pros:

Challenges include culture, salary revisions and lack of clarity in terms of progression and growth.
Conservative and hierarchical culture with quite alot of red tape.

pros: Work life balance improving. Plenty of opportunities internally. Was able to be part of a great time in Singapore.
cons: Number of processes to get things done. Working with London/NY counterparts will creep into overtime (unavoidable).

pros: The bank will still look after staff and won't fire people without any reason like citi bank or Barcap.

Outsourcing, such as ITSC, is big failure to the whole organization.  It cause in-efficiency globally.
Training budget seems to be cut always.

review_title: Used to be a great place but not sure if they are Here for Good now...

cons: Lack of diversity & fairness in certain departments where certain nationalities make up almost 90% of the team! Poor work-life balance particularly in Retail business. Bonus is not great.

cons: Most days it's more a roadshow sales man job than a manager who manages relationships. Management cultivates fear and is not in line with global EB

cons: The structure is as expected a little bureaucratic, but overall if you feedback to the managers they listen and they are pretty nice to you.

review_title: ok pay but work can be pretty heavy

review_title: New experience that I have never felt before

Friendly colleagues and supporting management. 
Good working environment.
Company provide transport to quite a number of locations in Singapore.
Here for good! :)
cons: Internship are not well coordinated. No programmes for interns to meet and no training are arranged for us unlike other banks.

review_title: Good organization but not for someone who wants to be in varied roles
pros:
- Good intro to a large co.
- There is a clear job structure
- Many staff perks (example: tie-ups with eateries)
cons:
- Difficult to move to other areas internally
- Decision making is not decentralised
- Not much consideration is given to staff from lower-level staff

pros:
- International branding
- Allows you to try new projects and new roles even without any relevant experience, all you need is a good network!
cons:
- Its all about who you know and the network. Ability and delivery comes secondary.
- The banded staff (1-4) are basically armchair generals... the rest does the actual work.

pros: multicultural, ability to do more than JD, mobility, the strength of the network
cons: top heavy, lack of discipline in execution, easily enamored by the external world sacrificing internal talent

pros:
Pay is above local banks 
Benefits are good including ability to encash part of the medical benefits, sell holiday days, access to cheap personal phone contracts, free tickets (subject to availability) for the zoo and night safari
cons:
None of the pros make up for the cons -

- Exceptionally political. 
- A lot of individuals not doing any work seem to survive thanks to a combination of sucking up to the boss and/or being from the same race and country (there is an Indian mafia, Pakistani mafia, Aussie mafia, British mafia and the only criteria for survival is to pick a team of the same nationality, any talent aside)
- a consequence of the nepotism is that there are a lot of unqualified resources who don't do much if anything and are still fairly safe despite any losses or failures 
- a lot of initiatives started with no hope of success and continue till it becomes so ridiculous that management pulls the plug. By this time, the MDs/ Ds and their cronies have gone through two bonus/promotion cycles and get an internal mobility out. The last patsy or the new one gets thrown under the bus. Rinse & Repeat. 
It's then somewhat surprising to see CEO and MT worry about why programs aren't generating returns. Surely you're all not that naive not to see that somee of your one and two downs are taking the bank for a ride. 
- Outsourcing to Chennai/ Bangalore/ Poland/ Tianjin may be cheaper but so badly done that processes still continue to sit in the original location while you now pay for high cost locations and low cost locations headcount.
Bear in mind that 75% of band 5, 6 and 7 resources fired doesn't mean that the remaining 25% will do 100% of the job while the low cost resources twiddles thumbs.

pros:
-rewarding

-decent pay

review_title: High pressure and fast-paced, but flexible with good benefits.

pros: Effective team collaboration and cohesiveness.

pros: Fantastic cultures structures in place to make employees comfortable, most importantly to ensure work-life balance. The bank takes personal development seriously and has a fairly good framework in place to support employees in this regard. Finally, work place health a safety is taken very seriously.
cons:
Too much power given to line management/business and HR has little or no influence on people welfare. All HR people policies and benefits are given at the discretion of the line management/business and consequently, the experience with different employees is not homogeneous across the bank. Until the bank addresses this structure, or better still, train managers on decision making when it comes to benefits, this will continue to be a pain and the will continue to lose goodwill. 

The bank itself has all the fantastic structures in place to be the best place in the world to work, but the people is the problem.

pros:
1. Pace of work is relatively relaxed
2. If you work on iOS app dev, you get a MacBook Pro
3. If you're a Woman then recently SCB is pushing more for female representation on top, so you can expect to get more attention from higher ups on your learning & career growth & promotions.
cons:
1. Their 6 weeks training program tries to teach you Front -end, backend & Database & JIRA; but it actually fails as you're taught everything for just 1 week & have to immediately switch to learning sth else immediately. And on top of that they expect you to implement these learnings & showcase in a project in those 6 weeks itself.
2. I'm from Tier -I college, & it's sad to see a very toxic hierarchy for salaries & promotions in place based on if you come from good college or not.
3. When you're allotted to a new team, it takes them 2-3 weeks to even fully provide you access to key software you need & there are just no mentors to guide & help you understanding the project you're working on.

pros:
- Good company policies for employees
- Zero toleration for misconduct
- Overall structure is supportive

- No unnecessary competition or politics(at least not on the managerial level)
-Very inclusive and warm work environment, especially for women
-Work-Life Balance is on point, no random or adhoc requests, proper compensation is given for overtime when and if the employee needs to work overtime
-Good place for a nice stable 9-5
cons:
- Everything is at the discretion of the Manager
- Hikes depends on team funding and not just on performance
- Random reason to cut down monetary compensations (budget cuts are real)
- Hiring grads from fancy Ivy leagues but not paying the current employees what they deserve(notice the pattern here?) puts you behind peers in other companies.
- Not much of a growth, kind of a chill out yet stagnant career path
-Not for ambitious people looking for challenges
